column1: Writing history was popular among Christian monks and clergy in the Middle Ages. They wrote about the history of Jesus Christ
column2: that of the Church and that of their patrons
column3: the dynastic history of the local rulers. In the Early Middle Ages historical writing often took the form of annals or chronicles recording events year by year
column4: but this style tended to hamper the analysis of events and causes. An example of this type of writing is the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle
column5: which was the work of several different writers: it was started during the reign of Alfred the Great in the late 9th century
column6: but one copy was still being updated in 1154. Some writers in the period did construct a more narrative form of history. These included Gregory of Tours and more successfully Bede
column7: who wrote both secular and ecclesiastical history and who is known for writing the Ecclesiastical History of the English People.
